answer: offcolor = onColorposition: was overloaded and had the setter, so removed that.used the cell inspector to find that the colors where the same and then spent some time finding the mutator of the value

One of the corner switches could not be switched on because the method LOCell >> #position contains logic to set the "on" color to the "off" color when the position of a LOCell was requested to change to a new point.I fixed the bug by removing the method.
bug-description: One of the corner switches could not be switched on because the method LOCell >> #position contains logic to set the "on" color to the "off" color when the position of a LOCell was requested to change to a new point.I fixed the bug by removing the method.

answer: Student datas are wrong for Adèle, there is a mistake space character in near the '+' marker. Fix it by editing student datas list in Magenta>>students  (remove the space).
bug-description: wrong data set with a not necessary space character

answer: because of trailing white space into the data 'Adèle +<space>'Fix: I removed this space.One could implement data sanitization.

In the class superclass of LoCell, there were a method getCorner and setCorner that randomly pointed to one of the corners of the grid in the class variabl corner. To fix the bug, I just deleted the part of the code in the instance method position: where it assigned the off color value to the onColor variable of thie designated corner.
bug-description: There was a method that assigned the off color vallue to the onColor variable in one corner chosen at random

answer: The oncolor was changed during launching in position: function, i disabled that part of the code.
bug-description: The oncolor was changed to disble for certains corners during the launch of the game

answer: The level marker had a space after it ('+ ') for the 3rd instance of Adèle. Removing that space fixes the bug (or alternatively, using some "starts with" logic could fix it, etc.
bug-description: The marker for Adèle 3 had a space after the + character. The logic to display the marker didn't expect that space to be there (the space was not easily visible in the GUI).

answer: Because the marker of this student have an additional space at the end of the string marker. "+ ". There is an if that compare with "+" without space.
bug-description: the bug was that the student mark has an additional space at the end "+ ". The the object that diplay the name was fixed to consider "+" without space.

answer: I was not able to fix it.I only put break point on the corner. However, the behavior was the same for each corner.
Because student marker =  '+ 'then( {'+'. '-'} includes: '+ ') = falseI fixed in the input string, but the correct fix should be in the reader, cleanning the input. or in the setter methods
bug-description: '+ ', input error, the string contains an space

answer: Because one marker of 'Adèle' is '+ ' instead of '+'. So we need to sanitize this string with trim to perform includes check.
bug-description: add trim after student marker to remove extra spaces

answer: the marker contained an additional space, i removed it in the students methods of the AmmoliteMagenta class
La variable onColor etait ponctuellement basculée sur offColor si la position est un corner... du coup on mettait bien la led à on mais la mauvaise couleur était affichée
bug-description: The wrong color is affected to onColor lors de la mise à sa position de la led

answer: the marker of the last student named Adèle has composed of a symbol and space.Basically the normal marker form is '+' or  '-'  nothing.The last Adèle marker form is '+_'To display it we have to add this possibility in the textPrintStudent:on: message
The marker of the last Adele had 2 characters instead of just one, a newline was added. So I remove the newline in the students method
The onColor was overriden on the top right corner to the off color. Then it was never toggling the Switch morph since it is based on the colors to check the state.
bug-description: position: was overriden in SimpleSwitchMorph and was creating a bad behavior

answer: I inspected all Adèles in the list, all of them are similar. Same types and values for markers. I couldn't find any bug there.So I went to debug the generate button.I guess the error was in textPrintOn:  method called in  displayGroups . Didn't have time to fix it.
In AmmoliteMagenta>>students, one of the Adele had a space character after the +. I removed it, it could be possible to make the code more ribust and handle the case but I am too lazy.
The SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: method was changing the onColor attribute of one of the corner cells incorrectly. Removing it and therefore only calling the superclass version makes it work!
bug-description: The bug was hidden in the superclass of the LOCell, inside the SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: method where it incorrectly sets the onColor instance variable to the offColor. This behavior was only triggered when SimpleSwitchMorph>>getCorner  was triggered.

answer: When the list of students is read from the disk, some of the markers had extra character (space).  To fix this, I transformed the list of students by trimming the markers.
bug-description: I think the bug was the extra characters in the marker and the way markers were compared in markerP and markerL. Due to extra space the object was not the same. I modified first the marker comparision apis (markerP and markerL) as I thought the way compairsion was done was incorrect. However, after some time I realiazed that it is the extra characters in the marker from the disk itself. Afterwards, I modified the student object to have trimmed markers.

answer: The marker of the last student named Adèle was not displayed in group lists because it was containing  '+ ' with a space after the plus instead of only the '+'.  The condition for displaying the marker was not met because it was not only + or -.If fixed that by removing the space at the end of the last 'Adèle + ' line  in AmmoliteMagenta class>>#students.

The root cause is that Adele's third record had a blank space after the Level +. This caused the marker property to have one more character in the object instance. This extra character causes a problem in rendering the object, so no value was displayed for this Adele object, not even the + character.I fixed it by adding trimRight to the AMGroup.textPrintStudent method, at which point the marker property is concatenated into a stream to be displayed in the listing.({ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker trimRight) ifFalse: [ ^ self ].This is certainly not the ideal way to fix the problem.The ideal way would be: (1) correct the data at the source (in the database), (2) add trimRight or trimBoth when loading the data when loading the Ammolite Magenta window, (3 - optional, maybe) correct the method that renders the string in the presentation of the groups.I didn't do the 1 because I don't have access to the data source.I didn't do the 2 because I believe the objective was to change the model and not the presenters.I didn't do the 3 because I didn't find the method that does this, I believe it's a kernel method.
bug-description: The root cause is that Adele's third record had a blank space after the Level +. This caused the marker property to have one more character in the object instance. This extra character causes a problem in rendering the object, so no value was displayed for this Adele object, not even the + character.

answer: The marker is a string and it was parsed from the file as '+ ', so later the comparison fails. I have added a #trimBoth in the loading of the file

The method `SimpleSwitchMorph >> #position:` runs some code to select a random corner cell and set its onColor to be the same as its offColor.Since this method only calls super besides making a cell buggy, I simply deleted it.

One of the corner switches below couldn not be switched on because:- at each click, the block called was calling LOCell>>#switch: which would call LOCell>>#setSwicthState: which would call LOCell>>#turnOn that would set the color to the color contained inside the `onColor` instance variable- LOCell inherits from `SimpleSwitchMorph` which overrides the #position: method which sets the value of `onColor` to `offColor`and this method was called  by `SimpleSwitchMorph class>>#setCorner` that would choose one random corner I fixed that by: - putting `HaltOnce` several times in `LOPane>>#toggleCellAt:` because it looked like a good starting point, considering `LightsOutGame` only references this class. I did this 4 times for each corner and with steps, I could find the chain of methods that were called and inspect the instance variables `offColor` and `onColor` for each corner. I found out that one corner had the same value for `onColor` and `offColor`.- browsing methods writing the instance variable `onColor`. Then I just removed the problematic method `SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position:`
bug-description: A method was setting for one random corner the same color for its `on` state and for its `off` state

answer: I created an inspector to check whether the light was on everytime I inspected a case.I noticed that it was always on for some cases.I checked whether onColor = offColor and found it was the case.I had the bug, just needed to find the root of it.I put checks in between every steps to minimize where I had to look.I ended up removing the code from position:  that was setting  a corner's color as the same ones

There were three methods added to the SimpleSwitchMorph, which is the superclass of LOCell:SimpleSwitchMorph >> positionSimpleSwitchMorph class >> setCornerSimpleSwitchMorph class >> getCornerThose methods were selecting the random corner cell and assigning onColor equal to offColor.I removed all three methods and now the bug is fixed
bug-description: There were three extra methods added to the superclass that introduced the bug by setting onColor := offColor for a random corner cell. I found and removed those methods

answer: There was an extra space after the marker that was not taken into account when parsing to an AMStudent was done.I fixed by trimming the value read before setting it as the marker
bug-description: extra-space in the marker not managed

answer: SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position: has a special case that overwrite the onColor with the offColor one when the morph is in a corner. It's not clear if it's a Morph thing but to brutally overwrite the onColor ivar when setting a position seems really weird and seems to break the whole `color`, `onColor`, `offColor` thing of the SimpleSwitchMorph class.My proposal cooul be to remove SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position: and check what break :)
bug-description: SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position: should not mess with colors (or should explain why)

answer: The marker of the last student named Adèle is not displayed because there is a white space in it and the method printing the marker looks for exact match with the string '+'.I fixed it by replacing the marker check with a more flexible instruction that checks if there is the character + or -  in the marker string.
bug-description: There was an instruction checking if the marker of a student is '+' or '-'.  If not it does not print the marker. Since the last student named Adèle has a white space in his marker, it does not print the marker because it does not exactly match the string '+'.

answer: I seeked for sender of AMStudent>>marker:  setter, found that it is caused by wrong initialization from a stream, where each line (representing student) wasn't trimmed for white space. Therefore marker contained additional whitespace. I trimmed line in `AMStudent readFromDataString: studentDataString trimmed`  of #AmmoniteMagenta>>promotion method. It took me quite time...
bug-description: Wrong initialization of student instance from a input stream (setting marker contained additional whitespace)

answer: In the dataset AmmoliteMagenta>>#students, there was a space taht should not have been there after teh '+' for the third Adèle.The easy way to fix that was to remove this space, which I did.In real life, I would have modified the code of Student to:- at least trim the level- maybe remove #marker: and rather add methods like #bePlus,  #beMinus or something like that and force their use to modify markers instead of a manual entry. That is a decision that must be taken by the developer.
bug-description: In the dataset, the last Adèle's marker was followed by an unwanted space

answer: The class SimpleSwitchMorph was changing the on color when setting the position of the switch in case it was a the corner returned by `self class getCorner`
bug-description: The bug was that setting the position of a switch was changing the on color of the switch if the switch was in a specific corner

answer: Dans AmmoliteMagenta>students, il y a un espace en trop à la fin de la description de la troisième étudiante : "Adèle + " il faudrait mettre "Adèle +" à la place.

a call to position: set the onColor to be the same as offColor. I noticed in the debugger that the two colors were the same. I tried putting a breakpoint when onColor was set but it hit too many times. I resorted to searching for references to onColor and findin where it was being set
SimpleSwitchMorph has an incorrect override of #position: which sets the colour of onColour to offColour. You need to remove this method
bug-description: SimpleSwitchMorph has an incorrect override of the #position: method that changes the onColor value

answer: I did not finish thIS task because I cannot find the problem
SimpleSwitchMorph class >> setCorner chooses one corner at randomSimpleSwitchMorph >> position: set onColor = offColor for this corner

LOCell>>position: was overriden in SimpleSwitchMorph and was setting identical on/off colors for a corner cell determined by the class-side methods get/setCornerCell switching is done based on the color comparison in LOCell>>switch:Removing SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: fixes the bug
bug-description: SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: was a malicious override that was setting the same color for on/off states. Because switching cells relies on color comparison, it doesn't work when both colors are the same

answer: The marker of the last student named Adèle was not displayed because there was a space after the marker. To fix the bug, I inspect this last student   I debug AmmoliteMagenta run. The correction is : To delete the space after the the marker of the last student: Adèle on the method students in AmmoliteMagenta

answer: there is a blank in the method AmmoliteMagenta>>students after the second Adele person.I fixed it by removing this blank.
there was a tricky position: that did onColor := offColor

answer: By some reason that I was not able to determine, the onColor and offColor instances variables have the same color when initializing the game. This only happens in one border

I could not determine which is the buggy method. I believe it has something to do with the fact the cells in the corners are either the first or the last in their rows, and there are verifications for "lesser than" (<) or "greater than" (>) in different parts of the code. Maybe one of this verifications is making the first/last cell be ignored, and it could be fixed by using, for example, <=. because there was an incorrect assignment in SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position: aPoint	super position: aPoint.	"this is your bug :P 	 correct fix here would be just remove this override but I'll let it here as doc."	"aPoint = self class getCorner ifTrue: [	onColor := offColor.	]"you can toggle, but you should never assign "offColor" to "onColor"

the level marker of the last student named Adèle is not displayed in group lists becasue in the list of students there was a space after the marke for the last student named adèle so I deleted the space

The list of students extracted from the method AmmoliteMagenta class>>students is a string, where each student is placed in a line. Its mark is followed by a cr Character. One of the lines containing Adele's name had an extra space after Adele's mark and the cr. To solve the bug I just removed the extra space.
bug-description: The bug is due to a format error in the input data that the application takes. To find the bug I had to place conditional halts and breakpoints to find where the student's name and mark were printed.

answer: Because has an space after the + in the definition of students.I fixed it first by removing the space in the "list" of students.Then I added a `trim` to the AMGroup >> textPrintStudent: student on: stream method to avoid this problem in the future
bug-description: The problem was an space after the "+" in the students list. Then a method in the group (AMGroup >> textPrintStudent: student on: stream) was performing a `{ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker` and with the space this is false.

answer: The data was wrong, the markers were strings, two of them were  just the + string '+', but the third one had a trailing space '+ '.I fixed it by trimming the data in the printing method.
bug-description: A problem in the data. One of the fields was a string with a trailing space. The App was not robust enough for this case when printing the item in the screen.

answer: The problem is that there is an extra space at the end of the the last Adèle in the students data, so the marker test in AMGroup>>#textPrintStudent: fails. The easy fix is to delete that space. A better fix would be to do some potential data cleaning in the AMStudent>>#marker: method.
bug-description: There was an extra space in the data that led to one of the students having a "marker" that was not recognized.

answer: The marker of the last studen named Adèle was '+ ' and not '+', so the condition on the second line of the method AMGroup>>#textPrintStudent:on: returned falseI changed the marker of this student to fix that
bug-description: the marker of the student had a space character after the '+'

answer: textPrintStudent: student on: stream		student textPrintOn: stream.	student name = 'Adèle' ifTrue: [ self halt ].	({ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker) ifFalse: [ ^ self ].	stream space.	stream << student marker asString	Here the code checks for '+' but some adele have '+ ' instead of '+' in their markers.I fixed it just adding '+ ' to the list. Another approach would be to clean the students markers using a trimboth on the markers. It would be cleaner to my taste. After a moment and because I could not see something obvious in display code I did(AMStudent allInstances select: [ :each | each name = 'Adèle' ]) collect: [ :each | each marker ]
bug-description: one adele object had '+ ' instead of '+' in its marker. I did not see it in the inspector in the first place. I spot super fast the place with the includes: but I could not see it because I got too many inspectors opened on the the three adele. So I started to frustrate :) so I started to forge the hypothesis that the bug was not in the code but in the data and then I decided to speed up and check if all the data was the same using (AMStudent allInstances select: [ :each | each name = 'Adèle' ]) collect: [ :each | each marker ]In the following I will consider that this expression is my debugging method. Because the debugger shows me fast that the code was not the problem.

answer: The issue was that the onColor was incorrectly set to offColor in SimpleSwitchMorph>>position:. When clicking on a corner the color was changed to the value of onColor, but that value was wrong. Deleting SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: fixed the issue.
bug-description: The method SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: incorrectly set the value of onColor for corner cells

answer: onColor and offColor are the same for one off the corner cell.In LoPane>>#newCellAt:, when the LoCell position is changed "onColor" take the value of "offColor" for some reason.
bug-description: onColor and offColor are the same value for one corner.In the method #newCellAt: from LOPane. When cell position is changed, it also change the onColor for one of the corner

answer: The reading from file was reading a marker up to the end of line, which allowed passing malforming strings with several markers on it. I did a dirty fix taking only a first marker up to the next space.
bug-description: Sorry, I didn't get the question. The type of the bug? What was the bug?

answer: because there was a space after the "+" of the last adèle, so to solve the problem I deleted the space, I could also have made the marker delete all the spaces
bug-description: they have a space after the marker

answer: The marker is '+ ' instead of just '+'. The fix sends `trim` to the marker before checking in AMGroup>>#textPrintStudent:on:
bug-description: '+ ' marker instead of '+'

answer: The method to print a student in the group, AMGroup>>textPrintStudent:on:, compares the student marker to a single character string, + or -. Other methods setting or using marker vary as to whether they expect a String or a Character. The Adèle in question has a string with a space at the end, so the simplest correction was just to remove the space from the string.
bug-description: One Adèle had a marker with an extra space at the end. Code setting and using marker varied as to whether it expected a String or a Character, but I didn't see any that would filter spaces from a string, so the immediate problem seemed more to be in the data. Rewriting everything to be consistent (or to use something more object-oriented than a String or Character) seemed a bit big for a first task. As the problem was in data not code, I didn't use the debugger.

answer: Method SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position: had code that set the onColor instvar value to the offColor instvar value if self is the LOCell instance that is answered by SimpleSwitchMorph>>#getCorner. The method could be deleted because the rest of the code only did a super call.
bug-description: SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position: had code to set the onColor to the offColor when it was the instance answered by SimpleSwitchMorph>>#getCorner.

answer: One of the corner switches was not be able to be turned off because there was a bug in the position method called when initializing the cells. I was struggling to fix the bug, it was not easy for me I looked at everything but I ended up fixing it by relying on the tip given, to inspect the faulty cells. The only difference between a 'working' cell and a faulty one it was that the onColor and offColor were the same or not. I knew that that was not good, so I tried to look at where those values were to be set. And I found that in the position method there was an assigment

The marker of the last student named Adèle was not displayed because her marker had a space in it and was '+ ' instead of '+'.I fixed it by triming the string of the student's marker  in the method `textPrintStudent: on:` in the class `AMGroup`.

The variable onColor whas set to the same value as offColor in one cornerI search for usage of this variable using the "Vars" part of the browser. I first did not found the correct method because the problem was not in the main pane in LOCell class, but the in superclass SimpleSwitchMorphI used again the "Vars part and discover lot of method using the variable, then I look at #position: and discover that this method had a strange behavior. In one case (I did not why/how), it modifies the value of onColor to assign offColor to it
bug-description: The value of inst variable onColor was overriden incorrectly

answer: SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position: refers to SimpleSwitchMorph class>>getCorner and sets a random corner to off.removing the method resolves the problem, as super position: will be called. Correctly removing it includes also removing the getCorner and setCorner methods, after verifying they have no senders
bug-description: Code was added to SimpleSwitchMorph to induce an error. the #position: method was overridden. It was made less visible by separating the error inducing behavior over multiple methods, two of which were at the class side

answer: I didn't fix the bug, however I noticed that the cell that doesn't switch on has the same onColor and offColor meaning that getting switched on make the cell switch to the same offColor. I couldn't find why it was the case nor why only one cell had this problem
The marker was not "+", but "+ ". I changed AmmoliteMagenta class>>#students to fix that.
bug-description: The marker for Adèle was wrong. It ended with a space, while the code has a condition on '-' and '+'.

answer: Inspecting the corner tiles showed that onColor was equal to offcolor for the problematic tile. This is done in  This is done in SimpleSwitchMorph>>#position:  and just uncommenting the code (just use the standard position:) seems to fix it
bug-description: SimpleSwitchMorph position: sets the onColor to be the same as offColor

answer: the LOCell>>#position: method set the offColor to the onColor of the cell. I just removed the method because it did nothing else.
bug-description: The position: method overwrote the onColor of a LOCell at a corner.

answer: SimpleButtonMorph>>position: is the main problematic method. It called super first, and made a call to a secondary bug inducing method. #position: is called at some point during the normal execution of the program. the secondary method at some point changed the value of the onColor variable of a random corner cell (and which should be yellow) to be gray (off). Therefore, when click the cell, the switch is performed but the on color is actually the off color. Poorly explained but the idea is there
bug-description: (same as the answer... I don't wish to re write this, so I paste what I copied just as a precaution)SimpleButtonMorph>>position: is the main problematic method. It called super first, and made a call to a secondary bug inducing method. #position: is called at some point during the normal execution of the program. the secondary method at some point changed the value of the onColor variable of a random corner cell (and which should be yellow) to be gray (off). Therefore, when click the cell, the switch is performed but the on color is actually the off color. Poorly explained but the idea is there

answer: `position:` method had a code where it changed `onColor` to be the same as the `offColor`.That code was executed only on one corner. Removing that code the game started working.
bug-description: `position:` method had a additional step that would make `onColor` be the same as the `offColor` on one of the corners.Since `onColor` and `offColor` are the same the switch didn't happen.

answer: When a cell is created, it's position is checked, however the position: method in SimpleSwitchMorph has a condition that overwrite the onColor value with the offColor value if the cell is a in a corner. I found the solution by setting 4 haltIf inside the LOPane initialize method, in the indicesCollect: block, when cells are created. I looked each corner values of x: y: and inspected each returned cell to see if the color onColor and offColor where equals. Then, I continu the execution step by step to see where onColor will get the offColor value.
bug-description: when creating a new cell, a condition was set to overwrite the onColor value with the offValue if the cell position was in a corner

answer: The level marker is not displayed beacause one of the students marker is '+ ', with a whitespace. Therefore, it is not equal to the control string '+' (without whitespace), and is not detected as a correct marker.To fix the issue, I added a call to the 'trim' message on the marker, so that it is correctly compared if there are any whitespaces in the string. Probably better to fix the system to create student and input the marker, but I don't know if such a method exists.Fix second line of method "textPrintStudent: student on: stream" in class AMGroup : ({ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker trim ) ifFalse: [ ^ self ].
At some point, when the pane use the position method it switch the onCollor to offColor it it found a corner, i simply delete that part of the code ifTrue: [	onColor := offColor.]
bug-description: Wrong behavior when it get the position of a corner

answer: The classification between + - or neutral was not consitent, One of the Adèle had a '+ ' marker instead of '+',  and thus wasn't properly identified while printing the marker and splitting in the stacks.

The level marker of Adele included an additional space, that always caused the comparison with the allowed markers to be false, during the printing of the groups.I fixed it by doing a trimBoth for the student markers.
bug-description: The level marker of Adele included an additional space, that always caused the comparison with the allowed markers to be false, during the printing of the groups.I fixed it by doing a trimBoth for the student markers.

answer: There is a bug into SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: the method change the onColor with the offColor when the case is on a corner.
bug-description: Problem is SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: method (see details in my previous comment)

answer: I can switch on all corners.I restarted many times the game, and I can always light on all corners.I probably missed something...

answer: Somehow, the onColor and offColor get set to the same (gray) value - I was able to find that inside the cell object. I could not manage to make object centric breakpoints work, when triggered, an error pane would open up on the bottom left displaying:Information**Debugger opening error**Original error: Break.Debugger error: Break.I believe I may have an incorrect setup to run the experiment.

One of the corner cell can not be switched on. however, the cell that can not be turned on is randomly or non0determinsistnc. It is hard to find which will be the faulty cell.  It can be due to position getCorner api.,

One of the corner each time had the same offColor and onColor. I discovered that by inspecting two tiles. I was looking for changes on the state of these variable but I did not manage to find the right moment in code execution to introduce the object-centric breakpoint for state acess that I wanted to use on the onColor attribute. I ended up identifying SimpleSwitchMorph>>position  as the issue using the var view in the browser. I am still not sure about where I could have activated the object-centric breakpoint.I solved the issue by suppressing SimpleSwitchMorph>>position
bug-description: The SimpleSwitchMorph>>position was setting the onColor of a corner cell to the same color as the offColor. Therefore the cell look was not changing when activating it.

answer: I think I found the bug. I removed the onColor := offColor line from the SimpleSwitchMorph.position method and it worked, the cell in the corner started to change color correctly.I tried using Halt on Call on the LOCell.switch method, this even gave some clues, helped to understand the call sequence of methods that use the onColor and offColor instance variables.So I analyzed the onColor and offColor variables of the corner cell instances and noticed that onColor was gray for the problematic corner, it should be yellow.So I tried to put Halt on State Access in the onColor variable of the problematic corner cell. However, when trying to debug, it displayed the error "Debugging opening error".So, after many attempts and already tired, I gave up on debugging and analyzing object instances and started looking at the source code randomly.So when looking at the SimpleSwitchMorph.position method, I found the somewhat strange line onColor := offColor, I found the code suspicious, removed it, ran it and it worked.I found it suspicious because there was no reason for a method called position to be setting the gray color to yellow.
bug-description: I think I found the bug. I removed the onColor := offColor line from the SimpleSwitchMorph.position method and it worked, the cell in the corner started to change color correctly. When looking at the SimpleSwitchMorph.position method, I found the somewhat strange line onColor := offColor, I found the code suspicious, removed it, ran it and it worked.I found it suspicious because there was no reason for a method called position to be setting the gray color to yellow.

answer: The method SimpleSwitchMorph >> #position: was changing the offColor to the same onColor when setting the position, this was not needed, and I removed the method
bug-description: The #position: method was changing the offColor for the corner position

answer: The method used for printing students in a group, `AMGroup >> #textPrintStudent:on:`, checks if the student has a marker  with the following check: `{ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker`.However the marker is parsed from a string by reading all the characters after the first space until the end of the string, in the `AMStudent class >> #readFromDataString:` method.The issue is that the last Adèle has an extra space character at the end, so the marker is '+ ' (with a space) instead of '+'.This results in the check presented above answering `false`, and the printing method ends early instead of printing the marker.A naive fix is to correct the `AmmoliteMagenta class >> #students` method to remove the superfluous space.A better fix is to make the `AMStudent class >> #readFromDataString:` method more robust by only reading one character for the marker, for example by using `next: 1` instead of `upToEnd`.

The level marker of the last student named Adèle is not displayed in the group lists because the method AMGroup>>#textPrintStudent:on: was expecting the marker to match EXACTLY either the string '+' or the string '-'. However, the marker of that student was '+ ' with an extra space. To find that, I checked with an object-centric breakpoint that the marker of the last Adèle was not rewritten or that it is not read in a weird way.Then, I found with the meta browser the method that prints the student in the group and put an object-centric method on that method for the last Adèle. I put another object-centric breakpoint on the same method for another Adèle to compare the execution of the method for both students.I found out by inspecting their marker that the problematic Adèle had an extra space in her marker, compared to the other Adèle whose marker is displayed.I just modified the condition checking on the student marker so that extra spaces do not matter. (Instead of comparing the marker with '+' and '-', I compare the trimmed marker with '+' and '-'
bug-description: The marker of each student was only displayed if it was exactly '+' or '-' . However, one student had an extra space in their marker: '+ ' , causing their marker not to be displayed

answer: There was an extra space after the marker for that adèle. That meant that it was comparing a string of two characters with only one.I removed the extra space, although there more resilient ways to fix it (such as a string search).
bug-description: Comparing a character with a string because an extra space was parsed with the + for that adèle

bug-description: The marker of the last Adele had an extra space

answer: The marker of the problematic Adèle ended with a space. The printing method AMGroup>>#textPrintStudent:on: that is used to show that person in the group below in the app, doesn't print the marker. This is because it expects markers to be exactly '+' or '-', returning too early when there in the case of this problematic Adéle.My fix what to only return early when the string is empty. It's not clear in the model if the marker should be either a normalized string or reified with a new Marker class with singleton instance, maybe.
bug-description: The students accepted any object as marker, so it doesn't ensure that marker is exactly '+' or '-'. But the printing method was expecting that the marker is exactly '+' or '-'.

answer: The includes method compares the hash of objects, and the object "+" is different for each student and evidently not the same as the hardcoded "+ . -" in the textPrintStudent method. To fix this, I changed the textPrintStudent method to verify the presence of +/- by calling includesSubstring instead of includes. While this solves the bug, I do not understand why it happened only for the "Adèles" in the array.

the error is in fact we being using a string instead of a dedicated enum object (Marker), hence allowing the possibility of instantiate a "marker" attribute with other value than "+", "-" and "none", which is what happened: The data to instantiate the student contained a string '+ ' (plus, space).For the purpose of the exercise my fix was simply to replace modify the #marker: method as follows: AMStudent>>#marker: anObject	marker := anObject asString trimmed	a more solid solution would be to validate the input in the marker: method (nil, +, -).But ultimately, the correct fix is to implement an enum class hierarchy (AMMarker, AMMarkerPlus, AMMarkerMinus, AMMarkerNone) which can parse maybe different kind of raw data but ensures the value we have there is correct (and it allows for better design of future implications of the marker)

I couldnt find the cause of the bug. I only figured out that onColor and offColor were both grey in the problematic tile. Also that old color was incorrectly set, probably because they are using fillStyle to update oldColor.

One corner had the same `onColor` variable as `offColor`, so the graphical application did not show the change.I removed `SimpleSwitchMorph >> position: aPoint` method with the malicious code. How I found it?1) Added a "break-on-call" on `SimpleSwitchMorph >> turnOn` method in the tile object with the bug. I realize that it was working as expected (setting the `onColor` variable as color).2) Then, using the inspector, I checked the `onColor` variable value, and compared it with other tile. They were different. And I realized that it was the same as `offColor`. 3) So, I added a "break-on-write" for the `onColor` for the buggy tile. It didn't hit because the variable was already changed.4) But! I opened the breakpoint navigator to see the methods that write the variable (4 methods). One of them performed `onColor := offColor`.5) Found it!
bug-description: One malicious method was setting `onColor := offColor`, so the color was not changed.

answer: The corner object has onColor = offColor.This happens because during the initialization of the cell, an overwrite decides to wrongly set the onColor := offColor if the position is a given corner.removing SimpleSwitchMorph>>position: does the trick

answer: The issue with the last marker is that the line in the data contains a space at the end. The method doing the reading readFromDataString: uses upToEnd which will also include the space. Because of that space when printing the marker in textPrintStudent:on:  the check `{ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker` will fail as the marker contains two characters, the + and a space. As a fix I updated the method reading the data for the marker to use trimBoth to remove spaces. `readStream upToEnd trimBoth`
bug-description: The issue with the last marker is that the line in the data contains a space at the end. The method doing the reading readFromDataString: uses upToEnd which will also include the space. Because of that space when printing the marker in textPrintStudent:on:  the check `{ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker` will fail as the marker contains two characters, the + and a space. As a fix I updated the method reading the data for the marker to use trimBoth to remove spaces. `readStream upToEnd trimBoth`

The LOCell's onColor has been set to be the same as its offColor in SimpleSwitchMorph>>position:, during creation. One corner is randomly selected per LOPane via #setCorner and checked via #getCorner by #position: during creation.
bug-description: Code was introduced to the superclass of LOCell to pick one corner per LOPane and set it so it effectively could not be turned on: its onColor was the same as its offColor. Not really a bug, more like deliberate sabotage :). [I'll treat "debugger" below as meaning "object-centred debugging". I didn't use it at all: just a simple breakpoint first to see why toggling the color in one of the corners didn't change anything, spotting that it was because onColor was grey rather than the normal yellow, then searching for methods that modified onColor. I didn't find OCD intuitive to use for *this* problem, but its functions are familiar and sometimes make debugging faster - even if you have to build the mechanism ad hoc as part of a normal breakpoint condition.]

answer: The datastring in AmmoliteMagenta class>>#students contained a whitespace after the '+' marked for one student called Adèle. The code that stores the AMStudent.marker instvar value does not trim whitespace.I found this by putting a 'halt on call' breakpoint on AMStudent>>#textPrintForGroup:on: for each Adèle student to see where and why the marker was not being printed.I fixed it first by removing the whitespace from the data string, but then found it was better to do a `trimBoth` to remove leading an trailing whitespace from the incoming string in AMStudent class>>#readFromDataString:
bug-description: Failure to trim whitespace from a string where it is assumed to contain only a single character.

answer: It was not displayed because there is a check to see if the marker of a person is included in {'+','-'} but the problem was that the marker of one of the Adele's was '+ ' that is the marker PLUS a whitespace. That's why the if was not being true. The problem originated from the string that contains all the persons names, there was a whitespace after Adele's name before the new line, so that made it into the marker itself. I fixed by putting a halt on the marker call

answer: The initial error is in the AmmoliteMagenta class>>#students method.The printing process compares the mark against '+' or '-'. The problem is that the method AmmoliteMagenta class>>#studentsreturns the list of students where the last Adèle contains a trailing space (after the +) unlike the previous Adèles.That is why it is printed different. To fix it, there are several choices. Once is to correct the input. Secondly is to add a step to cleanup the input string, removing problematic cases. And lastly, improve the printing method to make it more robust and ignore trailing spaces.
bug-description: The initial error is in the AmmoliteMagenta class>>#students method.The printing process compares the mark against '+' or '-'. The problem is that the method AmmoliteMagenta class>>#studentsreturns the list of students where the last Adèle contains a trailing space (after the +) unlike the previous Adèles.That is why it is printed different. To fix it, there are several choices. Once is to correct the input. Secondly is to add a step to cleanup the input string, removing problematic cases. And lastly, improve the printing method to make it more robust and ignore trailing spaces.

answer: Last Adèle had a trailing whitespace, which when compared to '+' evaluted to `false` so it didn't dipslay a marker at all.
bug-description: Last Adèle in the list had a trailing whitespace. Since it was read with `upToEnd` the whitespace was part of the marker.When marker was compared to `+` it evaluated to `false` and thus not displaying the marker at all.

answer: during the loading of the student data, the last Adèle on the list has a blank space after its + sign. During the group textPrintStudent: self on: aStream, the "({ '+'. '-' } includes: student marker)" compare the character marker, but the last Adèle comparaison add the extra blank space in it, which fails the comparaison
bug-description: an extra blank space in the loading data of the student after the marker sign of the last Adèle

answer: One light cannot be switched on because :- A cell has two variables, onColor and offColor, each containing the color for the "on" state and the "off" state- At each run of the game, one cell has their variables onColor and offColor with the same values, the original value of offColor. The cell therefore switches between the two same colorsTo fix it, I removed the method SimpleSwitchMorph::position: which calls the same method of the superclass, but also, for the first corner cell created on the game, sets the value of "onColor" to the one of "offColor".
bug-description: A setter (SimpleSwitchMorph::position:) was replacing the value of the variable "onColor" with the value of the variable "offColor" (so that onColor == offColor) for the first corner cell that was created.Therefore, switching the tile did change its color, but the two colors were the same.

answer: There was a 'getCorner' function implement ted in the Cell superclass that chose a random corner's onColor to be rplaced by the offColor by the position function. I removed the get Corner and setCorner functions and removed their calls from the position function.
